page.title: 15The Railway.
page.content: The Railway came to Bruton in 1856. Bruton Station was built on part of the field called Hyde, and to carry the old bridle path across the railway track, a bridge was built over it at the east end of the platform. This bridge was pulled down in 1956. Originally called the Wilts, Somerset and Weymouth Line, the Grea Western Railway (as it became) altered the scenery around Bruton and made the town more accessible. Trains still stop at Bruton, through not quite so regularly as they used to. Little of the original station now remains, since the old station buildings were replaced with metal shelters some ten years ago, whilst about two years ago the orginal signal box was pulled down and all that remains is a pile of bricks.
